original_title: Sri Lanka rupee closes stronger at 329/50 to the US dollar
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka rupee closed at 329.00/50 in the spot market, stronger from yesterday, dealer said close dealers said after moral suasion and direction, as bond yields continued to fall.
The rupee closed at 330/331 to the US dollar in the spot next market Tuesday, thought there were some sales at around 330 to the US dollar in the spot market.
On Wednesday there was moral suasion giving direction to the market, market participants said.

A reserve collecting central bank can control an exchange rate at will as long its open market operations are deflationary (triggering a balance of payments surplus) at the required interest rate to avoid liquidity injections (money printing).

Sri Lanka and most countries with monetary instability and external sovereign default use a confidence busting ‘flexible exchange rate’ along with flexible inflation targeting, where inflationary open market operations are deployed on reserve collecting peg on the claim that inflation is low.
The rupee has see-sawed from 295 to 320 and 310 to 330 over the past two months in the flexible exchange rate regime, which is neither a consistent peg nor a clean float.
A bond maturing on 15.05.2030 closed at 14.42/48 percent down from Tuesday’s 14.45/60 percent.
